snippet: Some officials are seeking the repeal of a New York State law that allows workers to continue receiving salary increases even if negotiations stall.
abstract: Public employees across New York State are working without contracts as labor negotiations stall because local governments say they cannot afford to raise wages; in many cases, unions are strategically deciding they are better off stalling negotiations now, given the state's grim financial picture, because under state law workers continue receiving longevity-based salary increases even after contracts expire.
lead_paragraph: Some officials are seeking the repeal of a New York State law that allows workers to continue receiving salary increases even if negotiations stall.

headline.seo: Unions in New York State Get Raises Even Without Contracts
headline.main: Even Without New Contracts, Many Public Employees Get Raises
headline.print_headline: Even Without New Contracts, Many Public Employees Get Raises
